marketNews.title: Indonesia Coal Export Decline Pressed by Weak China Demand
marketNews.content: Commodity analysis firm Kpler reported that thermal coal exports from Indonesia fell by 20 million tonnes to 150 million tonnes during the first four months of 2025, a 12 percent year-on-year decline, marking the lowest export volume in the last three years and the worst annual percentage drop since early 2017. The export decline in the first four months of 2025 was driven by weakening demand from China and India, both of which are experiencing increases in domestic coal production. Exports to China fell by 14 million tonnes, equivalent to a 20 percent year-on-year decrease, while exports to India fell by 6 million tonnes, equivalent to a 15 percent year-on-year decrease. Data from the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (ESDM) shows an even lower figure, with Indonesian coal exports since the start of the new year reaching about 131 million tonnes as of 16 May 2025. This amount meets only about 26.2 percent of the 2025 export target of roughly 500 million tonnes. For context, the ministry recorded that Indonesian coal exports in 2024 reached about 441 million tonnes, fulfilling only about 90 percent of the 2024 target of 490 million tonnes. The decline in Indonesian coal exports also occurred amid falling demand for coal-fired electricity. Think-tank Ember noted that coal-fired power generation across Asia fell by 3 percent year-on-year in the first quarter of 2025 as the region shifts toward clean energy and China’s industrial activity weakens. The shrinking export volume is likely pressured by reduced sales volumes of several coal issuers in the first quarter of 2025, such as United Tractors (UNTR), Bumi Resources (BUMI), and Harum Energy (HRUM). Nevertheless, some issuers – including Adaro Andalan Indonesia (AADI), Bukit Asam (PTBA), and Indo Tambangraya Megah (ITMG) – still recorded year-on-year increases in export and sales volumes. On the supply side, the ESDM ministry recorded that Indonesian coal production in the first quarter of 2025 reached only 171 million tonnes, a 16.1 percent year-on-year decline, meeting only about 23.1 percent of the 2025 target of roughly 740 million tonnes. According to a presentation by ITMG management on the 1Q25 earnings call, coal demand in the Asia-Pacific region is expected to fall by 71 million metric tonnes in 2025, mainly due to weakness in China. At the same time, coal supply in the Asia-Pacific is projected to drop by 27 million metric tonnes in 2025 as Indonesian production declines. Key Takeaway: We see that national coal production and export may miss the 2025 targets when looking at data from the start of the year. This aligns with the risk that several issuers will not meet their production targets due to weak output in 1Q25. We predict coal prices could trade flat in the range of US$90-100 per tonne throughout 2025, assuming: 1) weak industrial activity in Asia – especially India and China – amid U.S. tariff policies; and 2) high coal inventories in China.

marketNews.title: Other Hot News You Need to Know
marketNews.content: 1. A Bloomberg survey shows analysts and investors expect the United States to keep a 30 percent tariff on China until the end of 2025. Although lower than previous levels, a 30 percent tariff could eliminate 70 percent of Chinese exports to the U.S. in the medium term, according to Bloomberg Economics. 2. Bloomberg reported that since the beginning of May 2025, the Jakarta Composite Index (IHSG) has recorded a net foreign inflow of US$83.8 million as of 15 May 2025. If the trend continues, IHSG could end the seven-month net foreign outflow streak. Bloomberg says the inflow trend may indicate renewed foreign investor interest after confidence was eroded by concerns over slowing economic growth, fiscal policy, and global trade tensions. 3. Reuters reported that on 15 May 2025, SKK Migas approved Kuwait Foreign Petroleum Exploration Company (KUFPEC) to develop the Anambas block in the Natuna Sea. KUFPEC will invest about US$1.54 billion to develop the block to produce 55 million standard cubic feet of gas per year, with total gas sales projected at 185 billion cubic feet. KUFPEC aims for a final investment decision in early 2026, with production expected to start in 2028. 4. Malaysia and Indonesia plan to increase LNG import capacity, according to Takuya Tanabe, Head of Asian LNG Origination at JERA Global Markets. Tanabe said this could shift global LNG market dynamics, as Malaysia and Indonesia are the world’s fifth and sixth largest LNG exporters in 2024. Previously, Bloomberg reported in January 2025 that the Indonesian government asked domestic LNG exporters to postpone shipments this year due to rising domestic energy demand. 5. Bloomberg reported that Garuda Indonesia (GIAA) is in talks with BPI Danantara about a capital injection to improve the airline’s finances. The discussions are in early stages and details of the amount are still being negotiated. 6. Apexindo Pratama Duta (APEX) secured a contract worth US$25 million from PT Pertamina Hulu Mahakam for offshore drilling in the Delta Mahakam area of East Kalimantan for one year. 7. The controlling shareholder of PAM Mineral (NICL), Christopher Sumasto Tjia, bought approximately 1.3 million NICL shares at an average price of IDR 1,047 per share on 15 May 2025, a transaction valued at about IDR 1.3 billion. After the transaction, his direct ownership increased from 0.259 percent to 0.271 percent.

marketNews.title: 6 Calm but Profitable Investment Strategies
marketNews.content: "Only remember that there is no investment that is 'buy and sleep', there is a need to monitor its performance regularly to reduce loss risk and maximize profit." - JPH668

tickerNews.title: INTP reports 1.3% YoY sales decline in 4M25
tickerNews.content: $INTP: Indocement Tunggal Prakarsa recorded a 19 percent year-on-year increase in cement sales in April 2025, but market share fell to 28.2 percent (down from 30.7 percent in March 2025 and April 2024) as industry-wide sales grew faster (+29 percent YoY). Excluding the Lebaran seasonality effect by combining March and April 2025 data, INTP sales weakened by 3 percent YoY. Bagged cement sales grew 2.4 percent YoY, while bulk cement sales fell 14.5 percent YoY. Over the first four months of 2025, INTP sales declined 1.3 percent YoY (versus a 7.1 percent increase in 4M24), in line with industry sales which also fell 1.3 percent YoY (versus a 0.3 percent increase in 4M24).

tickerNews.title: GEMS announces 2024 dividend payout
tickerNews.content: $GEMS: Golden Energy Mines will distribute a 2024 dividend of US$500 million, equivalent to approximately a 106 percent dividend payout ratio, indicating a final dividend of IDR 309.15 per share and a final dividend yield of 3.3 percent as of Friday 16 May. The cum-date is on the regular market and negotiation on 23 May 2025, with payment on 5 June 2025. Previously, GEMS paid an interim dividend for 2024 of IDR 410 per share in June 2024, IDR 397 per share in September 2024, and IDR 244 per share in December 2024.

tickerNews.title: CITA approves 2024 dividend distribution
tickerNews.content: $CITA: Shareholders of Cita Mineral Investindo approved a 2024 dividend distribution of approximately IDR 1.3 trillion, or IDR 328 per share, representing about a 52 percent dividend payout ratio and indicating a dividend yield of 8.1 percent as of Friday 16 May. The cum-date and payment date have not been disclosed.

tickerNews.title: PWON completes bond tender offer
tickerNews.content: $PWON: Pakuwon Jati announced that it has completed a tender offer for part of its debt securities with a 4.875 percent interest rate on 15 May 2025. The principal amount paid was US$66.5 million, while the remaining principal outstanding is US$333.4 million. Settlement of the payment for the offer is scheduled for 19 May 2025.

tickerNews.title: INCO approves 2024 dividend and leadership change
tickerNews.content: $INCO: Vale Indonesia shareholders approved a 2024 dividend of US$34.65 million, or approximately IDR 54.3 per share assuming an exchange rate of IDR 16,500 per US$, representing about a 60 percent dividend payout ratio and indicating a dividend yield of 1.8 percent as of Friday 16 May. The cum-date and payment date have not been disclosed. Shareholders also approved the termination of Febriany Eddy as President Director and the appointment of Bernardus Irmanto as interim President Director.

tickerNews.title: GGRM injects capital into toll road subsidiary
tickerNews.content: $GGRM: Gudang Garam announced that the company has injected capital of IDR 1.5 trillion through a new share subscription in its subsidiary PT Surya Sapta Agung Tol. The transaction is intended to support the continued development of the Kediri-Tulungagung toll road project built by the company via PT Surya Sapta Agung Tol.

tickerNews.title: TPIA reports contractor incident at CAA plant
tickerNews.content: $TPIA: Chandra Asri Pacific clarified to the IDX that a contractor for the PT Chandra Asri Alkali plant, China Chengda Engineering Co. Ltd., was approached by a representative claiming to act on behalf of a local businessman in Cilegon, Banten. The company said the incident could potentially disrupt the previously scheduled plant construction timeline. The company also attended an investment dispute resolution meeting facilitated by BKPM on 14 May 2025.

tickerNews.title: FAST to divest 20% stake in PT Jagonya Ayam Indonesia
tickerNews.content: $FAST: Fast Food Indonesia director Dio May Avico said the company will divest a 20 percent stake in PT Jagonya Ayam Indonesia, a subsidiary that supplies chicken meat. FAST currently holds 70 percent of PT Jagonya Ayam Indonesia. The divestiture, without disclosed transaction value, aims to raise working capital and improve cash flow. The shares will be bought by PT Shankara Fortuna (15 percent) and PT Santosa Bersama Mitra (5 percent). On Friday 16 May, FAST shareholders also approved a private placement of IDR 80 billion from PT Gelael Pratama and Indoritel Makmur International (DNET).

tickerNews.title: WIRG shares sold by controlling shareholder
tickerNews.content: $WIRG: Controlling shareholder PT WIR Global Kreatif sold 72 million WIRG shares at an average price of IDR 84 per share on 15 May 2025. The transaction value was about IDR 6 billion and was intended as an internal strategy. After the transaction, PT WIR Global Kreatif's ownership in WIRG decreased from approximately 10.29 percent to 9.69 percent.
